article:
{{Infobox Historical Era |name = Victorian era |image = Queen Victoria 1887.jpg
|caption = Queen Victoria, after whom the era is named. |start = 1837 |end =
1901 |century = 19th |before = Georgian era |after = Edwardian era |monarch =
Queen Victoria }}

The 'Victorian era' of British history was the period of Queen Victoria's reign
from 20 June 1837 until her death on 22 January 1901. It was a long period of
peace, prosperity, refined sensibilities and national self-confidence for
Britain. Some scholars date the beginning of the period in terms of
sensibilities and political concerns to the passage of the Reform Act 1832. The
era was preceded by the Georgian period and followed by the Edwardian period.
The latter half of the Victorian age roughly coincided with the first portion of
the [[Belle Ãpoque]] era of continental Europe and the [[Gilded Age]] of the
United States.

Culturally there was a transition away from the rationalism of the Georgian
period and toward romanticism and mysticism with regard to religion, social
values, and the arts. In international relations the era was a long
period of peace, known as the [[Pax Britannica]], and economic, colonial, and
industrial consolidation, temporarily disrupted by the Crimean War in 1854. The
end of the period saw the Boer War. Domestically, the agenda was increasingly
liberal with a number of shifts in the direction of gradual political reform,
industrial reform and the widening of the voting franchise.

Two especially important figures in this period of British history are the prime
ministers Gladstone and Disraeli, whose contrasting views changed the course of
history. Disraeli, favoured by the queen, was a gregarious Tory. His rival
Gladstone, a Liberal distrusted by the Queen, served more terms and oversaw much
of the overall law-making of the era.

The population of England almost doubled from 16.8 million in 1851 to 30.5
million in 1901. [http://www.statistics.gov.uk/downloads/theme_compendia/fo-
m2005/01_FOPM_Population.pdf The UK and future], statistics.gov.uk
Scotland's population also rose rapidly, from 2.8 million in 1851 to 4.4 million
in 1901. Ireland's population decreased rapidly, from 8.2 million in 1841 to
less than 4.5 million in 1901, mostly due to the Great Famine. At the
same time, around 15 million emigrants left the United Kingdom in the Victorian
era and settled mostly in the United States, Canada, and Australia. [http:/-
/www.nma.gov.au/exhibitions/past_exhibitions/exiles_and_emigrants/ Exiles and
Emigrants]. National Museum of Australia

During the early part of the era, the House of Commons was headed by the two
parties, the Whigs and the Tories. From the late 1850s onwards, the Whigs became
the Liberals; the Tories became the Conservatives. These parties were led by
many prominent statesmen including Lord Melbourne, Sir Robert Peel, Lord Derby,
Lord Palmerston, William Ewart Gladstone, Benjamin Disraeli, and Lord Salisbury.
The unsolved problems relating to Irish Home Rule played a great part in
politics in the later Victorian era, particularly in view of Gladstone's
determination to achieve a political settlement. Southern Ireland achieved
independence in 1922.
categories: History of the United Kingdom by period
